article_title: Lawyers for health agency, religious nonprofits present case to federal appeals court
article_text:
Lawyers for health agency, religious nonprofits present case to federal appeals court Federal lawyers ask 5th Circuit panel to overturn ruling in favor HBU, other religious nonprofits on mandated

The federal government Tuesday took its case against Houston Baptist University and a group of other Texas religious nonprofits to the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, arguing that the groups not only want to deprive their workers of mandated birth control options but prevent anyone else from providing them.

article_metadata.description: The federal government Tuesday took its case against Houston Baptist University and a group of other Texas religious nonprofits to the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, arguing that the groups not only want to deprive their workers of mandated birth control options but prevent anyone else from providing them.  [...] resistance, charged government lawyer Adam Jed, unfairly would deprive thousands of employees and their dependents of all forms of contraception approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, even though workers might not share their employers' religious beliefs.  Jed's arguments to a three-judge panel of the New Orleans-based appeals court meeting in Houston, came as the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services sought to overturn a Houston court's ruling that the agency's mandate violated the non-profits' federal Religious Freedom Restoration Act rights.  [...] he said, the nonprofits' further resistance to insurance companies or third party administrators independently providing such birth control is "a novel concept under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act."
article_metadata.author.name: By Allan Turner
